inference: Per-session thermal energy and water footprint
Description: For each usage log session, integrate the water flow rate over time to get volume, combine with the average temperature above cold baseline to estimate thermal energy used, linking a single event’s water and energy footprint to its duration.
short rationale: Per-session energy/volume ties resource use to specific events, modestly profiling habits.

Description: Use session duration from usage logs, flow profiles from water flow history, and stable temperature levels from trends to classify sessions into comfort profiles such as ‘quick lukewarm rinse,’ ‘standard warm shower,’ or ‘long hot soak.’
short rationale: Classifies personal comfort/usage styles from flow, temp, and duration, revealing routines.

Description: Within each logged session, identify the interval where flow is nonzero but temperature has not yet reached a user’s typical comfort range and integrate flow over that time to estimate cold-start water wasted while waiting for warm water.
short rationale: Measures waiting behavior to comfort band, moderately exposing experience patterns.

inference: Scalding-risk episodes tied to real usage
Description: Detect periods inside usage log sessions where temperature exceeds a safety threshold while flow rate is high, indicating real scalding risk to the user rather than harmless brief temperature spikes with low or no flow.
short rationale: Finds high-temp risk during active use, reflecting safety conditions for users.

Description: Combine usage log duration, characteristic flow rate pattern, and typical temperature to infer likely activities, e.g., long medium-flow hot sessions as showers, short low-flow lukewarm sessions as handwashing, and long high-flow cooler sessions as cleaning.
short rationale: Infers activity types from flow/temp/duration, identifying what users likely did.

Description: Compare distributions of session duration (logs), average flow (flow history), and average temperature (trends) across seasons to see whether users take longer, hotter showers in winter and shorter, cooler showers in summer.
short rationale: Reveals seasonal shifts in duration/flow/temp, reflecting changing personal comfort.

Description: Cluster sessions by user or behavior pattern using duration and timing from logs, then compare average flow and temperature to estimate how much extra water and energy each pattern uses relative to its comfort level.
short rationale: Builds user/profile clusters on comfort and efficiency, strongly profiling individuals.

inference: Optimal flow and temperature combination for comfort
Description: For sessions that users repeat frequently (similar start times and durations in logs), analyze typical flow and temperature values to identify combinations that users implicitly choose for comfort, enabling intelligent presets.
short rationale: Derives preferred flow/temp combos for routines, revealing personal comfort choices.

inference: Heater capacity limit under real peak usage
Description: Identify time windows where overlapping usage log sessions create high total flow; examine temperature trends during these peaks to find where temperature drops because the heater cannot sustain the combined flow, revealing real-world capacity limits.
short rationale: Assesses system capacity during peaks; aggregate operational insight with low personal detail.

inference: Pipe and heater performance degradation over time
Description: Compare historical sessions of similar type (from logs) and similar flow levels (from flow history); increasing time to reach target temperature and lower stabilized temperatures for the same flow and duration indicate deterioration of heater or plumbing performance.
short rationale: Tracks equipment degradation via session temps/flow; technical, minimal behavioral exposure.

Description: Within longer shower sessions, detect phases where flow rate is lower and temperature is higher (soaking/washing) versus phases where flow increases and temperature slightly decreases (rinsing), using the joint flow–temperature trajectory constrained by the session window from logs.
short rationale: Segments personal shower phases, revealing detailed routine steps.

Description: Identify usage log sessions where users turn water off mid-session (flow near zero) while temperature remains high and duration continues, indicating that they lather or scrub with water off, reducing both volume and energy use at their chosen temperature.
short rationale: Highlights conservation behaviors within sessions, profiling efficiency habits.

Description: For all sessions, use flow history to get total volume and temperature trends to separate hot-water portions (above a threshold) from cold or lukewarm; aggregate per day to quantify what fraction of total water use is energy-intensive hot water.
short rationale: Aggregated hot vs cold share; system-level metric with limited individual detail.

Description: Flag usage sessions where integrated volume and average temperature are both significantly above the user’s own baseline, creating a per-session ‘excess energy use’ score that highlights unusually wasteful showers.
short rationale: Identifies outlier high-energy showers relative to a person’s baseline, profiling waste.

Description: Analyze sessions grouped by time-of-day using logs, then compare typical flow and temperature per group to see whether, for example, evening shower sessions use higher temperatures and longer durations, leading to higher combined water and energy loads.
short rationale: Shows time-of-day comfort and usage tendencies, revealing routine timing.

Description: Locate sessions with long durations, moderate flow, and stable warm (not extreme) temperatures to infer gentle hydrotherapy-style usage patterns, in contrast to short, hotter, or more variable-temperature sessions.
short rationale: Infers potential health-related routines from session patterns, sensitive personal insight.

inference: Impact of system recommendations on behavior
Description: Before and after giving user recommendations, compare session distributions from logs, and for each category track changes in flow and temperature; reductions in both per-session volume and temperature for similar durations indicate effective behavior change.
short rationale: Tracks behavior change after interventions, moderately profiling responsiveness.

inference: Comfort drift after heater setpoint changes
Description: When heater setpoints are changed, monitor subsequent sessions with similar durations from logs and similar flow rates; shifts in achieved temperature and any increases in temperature adjustment activity show how users adapt or struggle with the new setpoint.
short rationale: Observes adaptation to setpoint changes, reflecting evolving comfort preferences.

Description: Identify short sessions in usage logs and analyze their flow and temperature; if most of the brief session is spent at high temperature and high flow after a ramp-up, it indicates hot water use where cold water would suffice, wasting energy for minimal duration.
short rationale: Flags hot, high-flow short sessions, revealing inefficient personal habits.

Description: Within each session, check whether temperature briefly spikes above the user’s typical comfort range once flow ramps up and then settles; such overshoot indicates heater or mixing control that overshoots target temperature before stabilizing under real flow conditions.
short rationale: Detects technical overshoot during use; limited behavioral exposure.

Description: Combine integrated hot-water volume (from flow and temperature) with session timing from logs and a local emissions factor to estimate CO₂-equivalent impact per session, enabling carbon-aware feedback on user behavior.
short rationale: Estimates per-session carbon impact tied to user events, modestly profiling usage.

inference: Differentiation of cleaning vs personal hygiene by thermal and hydraulic signature
Description: Sessions with variable high flow and moderate temperatures, often irregular in duration, can be distinguished from more stable flow and warmer temperatures in personal hygiene sessions by jointly analyzing logs, flow patterns, and temperature traces.
short rationale: Distinguishes cleaning vs hygiene from session patterns, revealing activity types.

Description: Use typical session durations from logs plus flow and temperature shapes to determine when water is no longer being effectively used (e.g., flow near zero and stable temperature), enabling smarter auto-shutoff times tailored to usage style.
short rationale: Configures shutoff from typical patterns; operational with low personal exposure.

Description: For sessions of similar duration and time-of-day from logs, compute the variance in achieved temperature and flow; low variance indicates consistent comfort preferences, while high variance suggests experimentation or inconsistent thermal comfort.
short rationale: Measures consistency of comfort settings, profiling preference stability.

Description: Short sessions where temperature changes frequently, flow varies, and logs show unusual times or very short durations indicate that the user is testing temperature and flow combinations rather than performing full hygiene or cleaning tasks.
short rationale: Identifies testing/experiment sessions, indicating exploratory behavior.

inference: Correlation of high flow with lower temperature preference
Description: Across sessions, check whether those with higher average flow (e.g., strong spray) are associated with slightly lower temperatures, revealing a preference to compensate for strong flow with cooler water to maintain comfort.
short rationale: Finds preference correlations between flow and temp, modest behavioral insight.

inference: Identification of sessions with simultaneous thermal and volume inefficiency
Description: Flag sessions that are both long and exhibit high average flow and high average temperature relative to the user’s baseline, indicating events that are inefficient in both water and energy dimensions and prime candidates for conservation nudges.
short rationale: Highlights sessions that are wasteful on both axes relative to user baseline.

Description: Aggregate concurrent sessions from usage logs and sum their hot-water portions (from flow and temperature) to estimate peak simultaneous hot-water loading on the system, used to size heaters and storage appropriately.
short rationale: Aggregates household demand; system capacity view with minimal individual detail.

inference: Effect of low-flow fixtures on temperature experience
Description: Compare sessions before and after low-flow fixture installation by examining changes in flow and temperature for sessions of similar duration from logs; if temperatures appear more variable at lower flows, users may feel greater thermal fluctuation.
short rationale: Assesses experience changes post-fixture install; mostly operational impact.

inference: Detection of low-temperature long-duration rinsing habits
Description: Identify sessions with relatively low temperature but long duration and moderate flow, indicating users who prefer extended cool or lukewarm rinses, distinct from short warm hygiene sessions.
short rationale: Reveals preference for long cool rinses, indicating distinct personal habits.

inference: Quantifying benefit of turning off water while soaping
Description: Within sessions, locate intervals where flow is off or minimal yet the session continues per logs and temperature remains high; estimate avoided volume and energy compared to a hypothetical scenario where flow stayed at typical level during these periods.
short rationale: Quantifies conservation within sessions, tying efficiency to individual behavior.

inference: Matching heater ramp profiles to user routines
Description: For common session start times (from logs), analyze the typical temperature ramp behavior under actual flow patterns; if ramp-up regularly lags user arrival, preheating or recirculation schedules can be tuned to better align with real routines.
short rationale: Aligns preheat to routine start times, reflecting predictable user schedules.

Description: Find sessions where near the end, temperature suddenly drops due to external demand while flow remains similar, after which the session quickly ends in logs; this pattern shows users terminating showers due to abrupt cold shocks.
short rationale: Connects sudden temp drops to session termination, revealing user reactions.

Description: Simulate slightly lower temperature setpoints for sessions using the joint distributions of duration, flow, and temperature; estimate potential energy savings while keeping sessions’ duration and flow behavior unchanged, indicating where temperature reduction alone can help.
short rationale: Scenario analysis on lowering temps; low incremental personal exposure.
